STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
October 9, 2023
Jennifer McMillian
Fostering Futures
2008 Hogback Rd Ste 6,
Ann Arbor, MI., 48105-9751
RE: License#: CB810302599
Dear Ms. McMillian:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on . Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is
required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must
include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616 -204-6992.
Sincerely,
Pinkey Brown, Licensing Consultant
Pontiac, MI 48342
brownp2@michigan.gov
(248) 860-3012

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation
(1) An agency social service worker shall
complete a written adoptive evaluation within
90 days of the family signing an adoption
and prior to approving a family for adoption.
One of three adoptive case files reviewed did not contain a written evaluation
within 90 days of the family signing the application. The application was
submitted on 11/4/2022 and the report was written on 6/20/2023.
FOM POLICY 722.08D Treatment Plans; Agreement and signatures
Once completed and approved, the caseworker
must obtain signatures from the following
individuals, as applicable:
• Caseworker
• Supervisor
• Second line supervisor, when sibling in care
are placed apart.
• Parents who are a member of a participating
household.
• Youth ages 14 and older.
• Foster parents, relative caregivers, and
unrelated court ordered caregivers.

Three of six foster care case files reviewed (thirteen PATP’s) four PATP’s were
late and pass the 30 days required.
• Youth one report ending 3/15/23 PATP was signed by the foster parent on
5/15/23. Same youth report ending 6/13/23 the foster parent signed the
report on 7/17/23.
• Youth two report ending 12/31/22 PATP was signed on 2/9/23. Same
youth report ending 3/31/23 PATP was signed by the parent on 5/6/23 and
the foster parent signed the PATP on 5/8/2023.
• Youth three report ending 7/6/23, was missing the PATP for this report.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• No technical assistance was provided.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• No consultation was provided.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 2 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows.
SI#2023C0000541, report date 7/11/23 and corrective action plan submitted
7/20/23, was in violation with R400.12409 (1) Education policy. The agency is
adhering to their CAP as that has not been any repeat violations.
Interim inspection report dated 2/2/23 but completed 12/19/22, this was due to
CWLM system change over. The CAP was completed 12/8/2023. The agency is
following their corrective action plan as there are no repeat violations this reporting
period.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator (CA) discussed the barriers of the agency on 11/29/23,
and what has improved since the last inspection. The CA reported that agency’s
staffing turnover and having too many tasks to complete per case, contributed to
the agency non-compliances of the rules and/or contract policies. The CA
reported that the staff are newly hired, and already show signs of burnt out, and
being overwhelmed with the requirements of their cases. She reported this

contributes to timeliness of completing the required tasks. However, she reported
spending many hours in executive leadership, and meeting with staff to hear their
ideas, to come up with a strategy to create some relief for staff to improve morale
and client satisfaction. She also reported the agency was able to increase the
numbers of caseworkers from 10 to 12 and the supervisors from 2 to 3. She said
there will be 1 supervisor per 4 staff opposed to 1 supervisor per 5 staff.
Financial Overview
The agency provided their annual audit by an independent certified public
accountant and an annual budget for the current fiscal year. No concerns were
noted.
Staff Interviews
The staff interviewed reported loving working for the agency. They are provided
support from their coworkers and supervisors. The staff all commented that the
administration listen to what they have to say and put forth a lot of efforts to assist
them in solving any problems that may arise with the staff and their cases or
working with the staff to solve challenges. The staff reported something that can
be change in the agency is to hire more visitation staff and to be assigned 3 or 4
cases while in training. The staff also reported that the supervisors are very
supportive but they want the supervisors to discuss issues with them so they can
learn and tell them how to improve an issue oppose to telling them things are fine
when it is not.
Description of Agency Walk Through
There were no areas of concerns noted in the areas of the agency.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
The agency had three safety alerts.
Concern #1.
The unlicensed caregiver has a spa and there is no locked cover for the unit. There
is no alarm on the door that leads to the spa or rescue equipment available.
Resolution:
The caregivers own an inflatable hot tub that is located on their back deck. This hot
tub was measured to be 2 feet tall by the licensing worker on 9/13/2023. The hot tub
has a cover; however, it does not lock. The caregiver is unable to find a locking
cover because the sides of the hot tub are inflatable, and the locking straps sold in
stores require screws for the sides of the hot tub. It should be noted that the only
youth in their home is 14 years old and reportedly measures 5 ' 7" tall. The caregiver
also reports that the youth is able to sit in the spa without the water coming
anywhere close to his head, due to it being only 2 feet tall, and that he is never
unsupervised in the hot tub. The hot tub is primarily to help the relative caregiver
heal from a recent surgery. Additionally, the backyard is fully fenced in, with the
home being the fourth barrier, and the gate to the backyard remains locked at all

times. Lastly, the licensing worker installed a CPSC compliant alarm on the door
leading directly to the hot tub from the back of the home on 9/13/2023. Photos were
provided and uploaded in CWLM to support the alert being rectified. During the
entrance conference the agency confirmed staff went to the home and verified
compliance.
Concern #2.
Access was not granted to the bedroom in the basement. A photo is needed of the
room. If a bed is assembled in the room, a safety plan is needed. The licensed
caregiver has a hot tub. There is an alarm/chime on the door that leads to the hot
tub, however, it was inoperable. There is no smoke detector in the bedroom in the
basement.
Resolution:
Licensing Supervisor verified a working smoke detector in the caregiver' s
basement, as well as a working door alarm on the exterior door leading to the
caregiver’s hot tub. This was verified by the caregivers’ providing videos of both the
door alarm and smoke detector in working order, which were taken on 9/11/2023,
and sent to the Licensing Supervisor on 9/12/2023. Pictures from the videos are
attached to this alert. Additionally, there is an attached basement safety plan that
the caregivers have signed, ensuring that the room in the basement is only intended
for storage and cannot be used as a bedroom. The caregivers have provided a
picture of the room, as it was locked for storage purposes. During the entrance
conference the agency confirmed staff went to the home and verified compliance.
Concern #3.
The unlicensed caregiver’s have an inground swimming pool. There is a fence
around the backyard; however, a barrier is recommended around the pool. A safety
plan for activities involving the pool is needed. There is a bedroom in the basement
with a full-size bed and there is no means of egress. The foster youth utilize the
bedroom for play/leisure activities. A safety plan is needed to address proper
sleeping arrangements.
Resolution:
The entire backyard is enclosed by a fence, and the gate leading to the backyard is
self-latching and remains locked. There is a CPSC door alarm on the backdoor
leading to the pool, as the home is the fourth barrier to enclosing the pool. The
alarm was verified via video by the Licensing Supervisor on 9/13/2023. There is
safety equipment, including a reaching pole, for the pool. The youth in the home is
15 years old and according to his caregiver, is a strong swimmer. The caregivers
reported that the pool is only 5ft deep all the way across and that the water does not
come close to the youth head when he is standing in the pool. There is an attached
basement safety plan that the caregivers have signed ensuring that the room cannot
be used as a bedroom. All photos are uploaded in CWLM. During the entrance
conference the agency confirmed staff went to the home and verified compliance.

VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that Fostering Future agency will be issued a renewal of their
regular license.
10/6/2023
Pinkey Brown Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
October 9, 2023
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
